animalOfTheDay.name: sand dollar
facts: When alive, they are covered in tiny, velvety spines that help them move and feed.
They feed by filtering tiny particles of food from the sand using their tube feet.
Sand dollars are flat sea urchins that live on the ocean floor.
The five-petal pattern seen on dead sand dollars is actually their skeletal structure.

calendar.name: rhinoceros
facts: Rhino horns are made of keratin, the same protein as human hair and nails.
They communicate through grunts, snorts, and even infrasound below human hearing.
All five rhino species are threatened by poaching, with three critically endangered.
Rhinos have thick skin, but it can be sensitive to sunburn and insect bites, leading them to wallow in mud.

calendar.name: robin
facts: Robins are known for their red breasts, which are brighter in males during breeding season.
They are territorial and will aggressively defend their feeding areas in winter.
Robins sing year-round, with males using song to establish territory and attract mates.
They are one of the first birds to sing at dawn, earning them the nickname 'the early bird.'

calendar.name: rook
facts: Rooks are highly social corvids that nest in large colonies called rookeries.
They are among the most intelligent birds and can use simple tools.
They form lifelong pair bonds and often stay with the same mate for life.
Rooks have pale, featherless faces that distinguish them from other crows.

calendar.name: rottweiler
facts: They are powerfully built dogs with a natural guarding instinct.
Rottweilers are descended from Roman war dogs and were used to herd cattle.
Despite their tough appearance, they are affectionate with their families.
Rottweilers were one of the first police dogs and are still used in K-9 units today.

calendar.name: sable
facts: Sables are small, agile members of the weasel family with luxurious fur.
They are excellent climbers and swimmers, hunting both in trees and water.
Sables were once nearly hunted to extinction for their valuable fur.
They are solitary animals with large territories that they mark with scent.

calendar.name: salmon
facts: Salmon are anadromous, meaning they migrate from saltwater to freshwater to spawn.
Salmon are a keystone species, providing nutrients to forests when their carcasses decompose.
They use Earth's magnetic field and smell to navigate back to their birthplace.
After spawning, most Pacific salmon die, while some Atlantic salmon may survive to spawn again.

calendar.name: sand dollar
facts: They feed by filtering tiny particles of food from the sand using their tube feet.
The five-petal pattern seen on dead sand dollars is actually their skeletal structure.
When alive, they are covered in tiny, velvety spines that help them move and feed.
Sand dollars are flat sea urchins that live on the ocean floor.

randomAnimals.name: vampire bat
facts: Bat saliva contains draculin – an anticoagulant studied for stroke treatment.
Vampire bats share regurgitated blood with starving colony members – reciprocal altruism.
Vampires run on ground using folded wings as front legs.
They use infrared sensors on noses to detect blood vessels.

randomAnimals.name: wood frog
facts: Wood frogs are known for their extraordinary ability to freeze solid in winter and then thaw and revive in spring.
Their skin is very sensitive to moisture, so they often hide under leaves or in forest litter.
Their bodies produce a natural antifreeze that protects cells from damage.
They are terrestrial amphibians that live in forests but return to water for breeding.

randomAnimals.name: bald eagle
facts: They were removed from the endangered species list in 2007 after successful conservation.
Bald eagles aren't actually bald - their white head feathers make them appear so.
Their nests can weigh over 2,000 pounds and be used for decades.
They can dive at speeds up to 100 mph when hunting.
